title: Why does open data matter for Malaysia?
displayTitle: Why does open data matter for Malaysia?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. The government, businesses and citizens of Malaysia can use open data to bring about social, economic and environmental benefits.

In this module we’ll explore the following:
  • What is open data?
  • What is data?
  • What makes data open?
  • Why does Malaysia need open data?

title: Discovering open data – in 2 minutes
body: ODI Trainer Dr David Tarrant explains what data is, what makes it open and why we need open data.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

title: From raw material to new information and knowledge
displayTitle: From raw material to new information and knowledge
body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.

title: What makes data open?
body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.

title: Why does Malaysia need open data?
displayTitle: Why does Malaysia need open data?
body: Open data can help bring diverse benefits to the government, businesses and citizens of Malaysia.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Transforming government
_items.body:
Open data can help make governments more transparent. It can provide the evidence that public money is being well spent and policies are being implemented.

For example, the Malaysian Digital Economy Corporation (MDEC) Big App Challenge provides students and academics to use the opportunities presented by Big Data Analytics and Open Government Data to develop apps to solve problems in society. Those who win the competition get to join the Big Data Accelerator programme and the grand winner gets a chance to visit the startup scene in the UK.
Take me to the MDEC Big App Challenge article

Elsewhere in government, the Sinar project is helping to improve citizen access to important civic information like legislative proceedings, parlimentary data and MP statistics through an open database anyone can access, use and share.
Take me to the Sinar project website

At a regional level, the development of the Asian Open Data Alliance offers new opportunity to collaborate on the release and uptake of open data acorss national boundries.
Take me to Asian Open Data Alliance article.

_items.title: Building new business opportunities
_items.body:
Open data is opening up new opportunities for businesses to connect with customers.

In Nepal, the Kathmandu Living Lab is using civic-tech to help businesses deliver better services through the use of open data
Take me to the Kathmandu Living Lab.

In India, specialist service housing.com is using open data to optimize real estate market, help people choose a place to live, proximity, building part of governmental assets not known in eight major cities
Take me to Housing.com.

In Bankok, Thailand, business Youpin.city is using open, citizen-volunteered data to map street probles and provide updates direct to the user on street conditions.
Take me to Youpin.city.

_items.title: Protecting our planet
_items.body:
In singapore, the National Environmental Agency has launched the ‘Dengue Website’, a data driven ‘cluster map’ that gives information on the location of dengue clusters, as well as preventative measures. The map is also now available through the NEA’s my ENV app for smartphones, providing increased functionality for users.
Take me to the Singapore case study.

For the city of Jakarta, Indonesia, flooding is a severe risk. Service PetaJakarta is a real-time map of flood conditions. The map combines citizen reporting, social media, government flood alerts and sensor data to provide critical information during flooding.
Take me to Peta Jakarta case study

In Sri Lanka, World Bank-backed project Global Facility for Disaster Reduction & Recovery (GFDRR) Open Cities project is creating an open data ecosystem that will facilitate innovative, data-driven urban planning and disaster risk management.Take me to GFDRR article

title: Are you ready for open data?
displayTitle: Are you ready for open data?
body: There are four helpful things to remember when thinking about opening your data. Can you remember them?

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses
data that anyone can access, use and share
data that is visible on the Web

title: Open data
displayTitle: Open data
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is a raw material for the digital age but, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its potential for creating new value.

Open data can transform interaction between the government, businesses and citizens of Malaysia. It has the power to help improve services, grow economies and protect our planet.
Content created by The Open Data Institute
